definition:
Let $G$ a group acting on itself by conjugation. Let $X$ be a subset of
$G$. The stabilizer of $X$ is called the *centralizer* of $X$ and it’s
the set $$C_G(X)=\{g\in G :  gxg^{-1}=x\quad\mbox{for all }x\in X\}$$

For any group $G$, $C_G(G)=Z(G)$, the center of $G$. Thus, any subgroup
of $C_G(G)$ is an abelian subgroup of $G$. However, the converse is
generally not true. For example, take any non-abelian group and pick any
element not in the center. Then the subgroup generated by it is
obviously abelian, clearly non-trivial and not contained in the center.
